author: b.rad.c
title: Decentralized Journalism Protocol
description: News articles suffer from broken links, article versioning lacks transparency, profit models value hyperbole over facts, and the lack of a neutral third party review decreases trust in news.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal is for the implementation of a protocol named dBranch that aims to break journalism up into several branches: contributors (journalists), researchers (investigative journalists), reviewers, studios, curators and the audience. The aim is noble and achieving it is important in the days of capitalist-controlled journalism which gets funded by the government in positive feedback leading to an unholy coalition. The proposal presents a pleasant read on the possibility. One such example is like the following comment in the proposal “ reviewer is independent of a news outlet their incentive is not to maximize the reach of a news article so they can be as honest as they like” these are excellent features to have and can open up new ways of generating valid reviews with inherent compensation for the reviews. The protocol is providing an excellent use case for Cardano in the important domain of news and knowledge production, evaluation and presentation. The proposal is in alignment with the ethos and aim of Cardano.
f6_assessments.q1: In order to evaluate the proposer's capability and commitment, we can see the activity in the dBranch codebase in github. The application is actively in development with about 60+ commits in the last 2 months that's a commit per day. The proposer is already spending substantial effort on the project. The proposal has been broken into four phases of one-month development each of which seems reasonable and doable. He has about 15 years of experience in their related field and the breakdown of the complex subject in the proposal and in the white paper is fairly self-explanatory which presents the clarity of the idea in the proposer's mind. With this evaluation, we can come to the conclusion that the proposer has the necessary technical capability to succeed in the endeavour.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer has enclosed a spreadsheet for the cost calculation that includes, business development consultation and engineering team consultation for 20K USD in addition to $36KUSD for the developer at the rate of $75 per hour for 480 hours over four months at the rate of 30 hours per week. There is a scope to quantify the 480 hours of development. The proposer will be hiring one or two others with experience in business development and building engineering teams to create a sustainable business plan including engineering and marketing teams. The rest is for hosting charges for the infrastructure for 12 months. The rates are reasonable and the costs are justified. The return and sustainability of the project are issues. The proposer has also recently received a micro-grant from IPFS to sustain development of a prototype and expects to get more fund to launch the proposal in a full-scale sustainable model. Therefore the complete exercise is for bold experimentation that will require more funding to make it into a production-grade system.

The hype over the truth and the lack of neutral third-party reviews reduce trust in the news. The team is working on a solution to partially solve that by using the IPFS protocol and blockchain to create an immutable, verifiable publication history, from which to select the right article content.
It is very good if this proposal, the IPFS protocol is implemented on the Cardano blockchain. We know the journalism industry has many problems, but this proposal reduces negative issues and increases positivity and consumer interest in this field. Therefore, when deployed with the Cardano blockchain, it promises to add value to the Cardano ecosystem. Such is the dramatic impact of this proposal on the Cardano blockchain and the Cardano ecosystem. In addition, the proposal can scale and explain the future challenge of journalism. The opportunity to apply the practice of development in modern society is too great - because the society cannot do without the press at any time, the proposal can completely scale up and solve the problem. challenges - there is plenty of room to continue to grow and expand. I strongly agree with the impact of the proposal, I vote 5 stars.

f6_assessments.q2:
The roadmap of the proposal is presented in quite detail, lasting for 4 months with important milestones divided by month. This is a reasonable roadmap and milestone for a proposal that takes time to implement. The work steps to be performed in each stage are very specific and in a step-by-step sequence - containing all the necessary information. However, I still advise the author to attach the milestone roadmap to specific months of the year (January, February,... - this is just an example). If so, it will make it easier for the community to evaluate the transparency and auditability of the proposal. As a PA, I have evaluated several proposals and have found that not many teams do this.
I don't feel satisfied without the presence of job performance indicators (KPIs) and key metrics. The author needs to look more carefully and specifically to come up with KPI criteria and key metrics. We all know the role of KPIs and key metrics in auditing. I consider KPIs to play a specific role in demonstrating the transparency and auditability of the proposal. So my advice is to quickly add KPIs and key metrics to the proposal. By doing that, this proposal will have higher transparency and auditability.
I think the author defines "what the success of this project looks like" in a way that is clear, very real, and easy to understand: Creating a world that trusts more journalism; Information disseminated on the internet will be standardized; Link decay will be reduced to near zero; The fact-checking and review process is more in line with the scientific process. I agree with the author's definition of such success.
Throughout the proposal, problems and solutions were clearly described. In summary, I hope that the author will consult my comments, taking note of the addition of KPIs & key metrics. I both agree and disagree with the auditability of the proposal. I vote 3 stars.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal strongly addresses the challenge, providing a pitch for a product that has unique qualities and attempts to address a key social problem.

As someone with roughly 20+ years experience in the media and media relations, this absolutely must be said: Most of the journalism-centered proposals I've seen on Catalyst amount to the old and arguably broken strategy of "Pay us to build a website, and then also pay us to pay freelance journalists to write articles for us." And, assuming it's even successfully implemented in the first place, all this really gets you is... a pro-crypto website. There's nothing interesting or new or special about that. Arguably, it's painfully redundant. Honestly, it's made me a little jaded about these proposals and so I've been a tough critic in assessing them in previous funds.

But I have to give this proposer credit, in that at least he's trying to use the tech Cardano is based on to innovate, and leverage the power of innovation to enhance the quality of information people receive through media. That's a real new product, something unique that the Cardano community could sell. And that makes it something special. And that alone merits a 5-star ranking for rising to the essence of this challenge. 

The big question that remains is chances for success...
f6_assessments.q1:
Writing the following with it being fully in mind that the proposer is upfront that this is a proposal for protocol development and thus in a very early stage: Generally speaking the roadmap is ambitious but looks fair, the biggest weakness here is the lack of a team.

I'm aware that the proposer has made team development part of its roadmap, but the proposal would be distinctively more compelling if it wasn't just one "jack of all trades" at this point behind such an ambitious project.

That being said, the proposer is open about this, I'm mainly highlighting this to say: This will absolutely have to be a focus moving forward. 

As for the budget, some more information might have been nice. But since, again, the proposer is upfront that this is the phase in which he will be seeking business/engineering expertise and using budget funds to do so, this should not be a huge problem *so long as the proposer engages very proactively with the community while progress is being made on these fronts*.
f6_assessments.q2:
It's good that progress on this will be open to the public. It's better that the proposer will post videos on YouTube demonstrating their results, and publish business and engineering plans. What would have been better, was something more numerically based. How often will you post progress reports and videos? Every other week? More frequently? Less? 

Forcing oneself to fit a schedule can be an intimidating prospect, but it does much for your proposal because it shows a willingness to work toward meeting commitments. This is especially important in a deadline-heavy field like journalism! For this reason, the auditability of the proposal doesn't quite reach a perfect score.

An open point with the budget would be the 10% margin that is mentioned. If this is meant as a profit margin I would doubt that this should be founded. The proposer should think about taking this part out of the calculation to give the community the feeling to not fund somebodies wealth but to fund their work. Nevertheless all costs are transparent and this can be seen as a positive point over all.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposer, Brad Corlett, is trying to solve the problem by creating a trustless news source that uses the Cardano blockchain for immutable and historically accurate and auditable publications which eliminates the possibility for link rot and having a permanent news articles for future generations to come. The product as of now is in it's infant stages but the hopes of this proposal is to create a beta version of the idea that will allow further development. The proposer has created a white paper shared via a link here: (https://dbranch.news/dBranch-white-paper-v1.pdf). Within this document the proposer has a well thought out and detailed explanation to the overall vision of this solution, most importantly to provide an unbiased news source that is reviewed and published only after it's declared credible and while remaining untampered with the help from Cardano's blockchain technology. With the use of DAOs, the Dbranches* throughout the whitepaper for future community involvement behind the core proposal and it's functions, will be completely decentralized, which is a very strong aspect of Cardano and it's ecosystem as a cryptocurrency changing the world through blockchain technology. This proposal is but a stepping stone into what the mainstream media could look like in 10-20years time, but it must start somewhere to ensure the public is receiving quality and accurate news that's not manipulated by big news outlets for their own personal gain to exposure and the possible creation of 'fake news' that we've been enduring throughout the past. This proposal's impact as it stands is given a 4 based on the progress of the idea thus far, but the proposer hopes that with funding, and returning to Catalyst in future funding rounds, to create a top notch product that deserves a 5 star rating.
f6_assessments.q1: The core of the problem lies in the solution, as there is no decentralized news outlet in the world today utilizing blockchain technology. The proposer has devised a sensible plan to kickstart the development process of the functionality of the product, building a foundation to create a business model capable of producing a team in order to complete the tasks outlined within the whitepaper provided; link previously shared. The proposer, Brad Corlett, has described himself as a jack of all trades, having 10 years experience in media at Premiere Digital Services, a documentary film maker of 8 years and six years as a full stack developer. He has provided a Linked-In profile (https://www.linkedin.com/in/bradcorlett/), and his social media twitter & youtube channels within the proposal. Admittingly, Brad understands he doesn't have a large social media following but he does have a huge idea being presented to Project Catalyst in this funding round. The budget for this proposal is set to allow for growth of the solution to the problem, including the developing cost, cloud services necessary for web services and storage, as well as consultation cost to refine a concrete business model moving forward and expanding the team. With the given timeline of 4 months, this proposal could return to Catalyst upon completion of the tasks outlined here for additional funding. The impact rationale for this first phase is a 4 based on experience of the proposer and the likelihood of the solution to the problem being implemented successfully if funded.
f6_assessments.q2: As stated by the proposer, this proposal seeks to create a beta product and after some backend development, produce a business model for a future funding round. In regards to the auditability of the proposal, the community will be able to review the open source code and download the software being used to check the progress being implemented of the outlined features. The proposer has also provided a link to Github, where milestones from the roadmap can be documented and viewed by Project Catalyst to maintain transparency (https://github.com/b-rad-c). This proposal has very little risk at this time, as it is to create a beta product, with the real risk coming at a later date once a working version of the solution is designed and further development is needed from newly recruited members of the team. Finding those developers within their specified fields of expertise may be difficult unless they're presented with an ample opportunity to build off of a working beta. The KPI's of this proposal are yet to be determined but the SDG goals are to create a sustainable source of accountable trustless and transparent institution based on information provided by the Dbranch.news. A rational score for auditability is also given a 4.

solution: Our protocol will use IPFS content addressing and the blockchain to create an immutable, auditable history of publication. Our neutral UI will force external reviews that disincentive sensationalism.
experience: I have 10+ years of experience in the media industry. Several as a doc filmmaker and 6+ as a software developer. My experience as a generalist allows me to envision the final product and build a team of experts to go from prototype to beta to final product.
